channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'The sooner we finish, the better,' says Joe Biden
item.description: The US president says US troops are on track to end evacuations by a 31 August deadline.

item.title: Biden: 'Taliban helping us get people out of Afghanistan'
item.description: The US says evacuation efforts to help people get out of Afghanistan are 'on pace' to meet a 31 August deadline.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban tell working women to stay at home
item.description: Women are not to go to work until procedures are in place to ensure their safety, the Taliban say.

item.title: US House approves Biden's $3.5tn domestic budget blueprint
item.description: The resolution allows Mr Biden's Democrats to move forward with their domestic policy proposals.

item.title: Could this solar farm be a climate change solution?
item.description: UN experts say rapid innovative solutions are needed to end our dependency on fossil fuels. Could this new project provide an answer?

item.title: Japanese yakuza mobster sentenced to death
item.description: Nomura Satoru denied ordering four assaults, one of which was deadly.

item.title: Russian toddler lost in woods for four days vows 'never again'
item.description: The 22-month-old Russian girl was found alive by a search party, four days after she wandered off.

item.title: German poison probe after drinks spiked at university in Darmstadt
item.description: Six people were taken to hospital with bluish extremities after using a science department's tea area.

item.title: Convicted ex-Chadian leader Hissène Habré dies at 79
item.description: The former president, whose government carried out 40,000 murders, was serving a life sentence.

item.title: VR helps Indians and Pakistanis visit their lost homes
item.description: Indians and Pakistanis who fled their homes during partition can now revisit their childhood - virtually.

item.title: How losing his sight spurred cyclist Steve Bate to the Paralympics
item.description: Steve Bate was told he could be blind within four years - now he's defending his Paralympic title.

item.title: Fire at Mexican offshore oil platform kills five
item.description: The incident comes weeks after a gas leak caused a fire on the ocean's surface near another platform.

item.title: R. Kelly trial: Woman says singer pressured her to have abortion
item.description: The second accuser to testify against the singer says he abused her and urged her to get an abortion.

item.title: Madagascar on the brink of climate change-induced famine
item.description: The country is on the brink of experiencing the world's first "climate change famine", the UN says.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: The lowdown on being disabled in Japan
item.description: From moon riders to job quotas, three residents give the lowdown on being disabled in Japan.

item.title: Can the US crack down on fake vaccination cards?
item.description: As more people are asked to prove vaccination status, a black market in fake health cards has boomed.

item.title: A Kabul evacuee's tale: Dread, chaos and the Taliban
item.description: An Indian woman tells the BBC of the on-and-off trauma of getting out of Taliban-held Afghanistan.

item.title: How Afghanistan rattled Asia and emboldened China
item.description: US VP Kamala Harris tries to reassure Asian allies, as many ask: can they still trust America?

item.title: Afghanistan evacuation: Bittersweet relief for interpreter now in UK
item.description: An ex-interpreter for the British Army is happy to have escaped Kabul but still worried for his family.

item.title: Taliban to US: Don't encourage Afghans to leave, we need them
item.description: Foreign countries should stop encouraging Afghans to leave their country, a Taliban spokesman says.

item.title: How are women in Afghanistan reacting to Taliban takeover?
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani speaks to women in Afghanistan about the Taliban takeover.

item.title: Afghan para-athlete Nilofar Bayat welcomed by new team in Spain
item.description: Nilofar Bayat, Afghan wheelchair basketball women's captain, is in Bilbao after fleeing the Taliban.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... Trump's Taliban deal
item.description: A deep dive into the US-Taliban deal of 2020 and its role in the militant group's takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Sandhurst Sisterhood helping female Afghan soldiers to flee
item.description: Major Alice Bromage is part of a network helping female Afghan soldiers looking to flee the Taliban.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: Afghanistan: Foreign troops extension 'a clear violation' - Taliban
item.description: A Taliban spokesman says Afghans with passports can leave on commercial flights "at any time".

item.title: Afghanistan: Where will refugees go after Taliban takeover?
item.description: Thousands of people are scrambling to flee Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: People at Kabul airport flee Taliban with just a suitcase
item.description: Afghans waiting at Kabul airport tell the BBC of their pain at fleeing the country they love.

item.title: 'Hours not weeks for UK Afghan evacuation'
item.description: The defence secretary says the UK will leave Kabul alongside next week's planned US withdrawal.

item.title: Afghanistan: The BBC's Lyse Doucet reports from Kabul airport
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet witnesses Afghan men, women and children fleeing the Taliban regime.
